body: @zaayer Did you follow the readme instructions for installing the terminfo file?
@chrisduerr Yeah, I did follow it. Before I installed it, I had an issue that nvim italics weren't working, but now using alacritty as my TERM allows nvim to display everything correctly.
@zaayer I know the default version of bash on macOS is ancient, have you tried it with a more up to date version? You can probably install it through homebrew or similar.
@chrisduerr Iâ€™m actually using the home brew installed fish. Once I get back to my computer I can try it with bash to see if the issue persists.

@chrisduerr Sorry about the delay on this, ended up having to travel for work and didn't bring my macbook with me. So I installed the latest bash using brew and the issue is also occurring in bash. I checked both using TERM = alacritty and TERM = xterm-256color and the same issue happens in fish as documented in my first post.

I also tried TERM = alacritty-direct and it has the same issue as alacritty (I'm not sure what the actual difference is between the two, but just wanted to verify).

@chrisduerr OK - I've found out how to fix it.

I was comparing the xterm-256color terminfo to the alacritty terminfo file and I found that alacritty.info uses 0x10000 for pairs# which is the decimal equivalent of 65536. xterm-256color uses pairs#32767.

I changed the alacritty.info to "pairs#0x7FFF" and now htop and nvim have zero issues.

I can submit this as a pull request, but fairly new to all of this (and its a very, very minor change), but I am not aware of what kind of downstream impacts that may have.

Let me know what you think.

That's very interesting! It seems odd to me though that with a lower pairs value, the color starts rendering. I'd expect it to be the opposite way around.

Please do send this as a PR, I think this should be fine when xterm uses the same value here. If I had to take a guess, maybe we're running into an overflow here? But then it shouldn't work on other systems, but it works just fine for me. Though macOS has a super ancient bash by default, so who knows.

Thanks for looking into this.

Greetings,

I want to mention that I also get that issue, but I'm using `zsh` (not Apple default, but one install with `Homebrew`), with the 5.6.2 version.

I'm running OSX 10.14.

Thanks for your time.

issue.title: Fix alacritty.info color pairs to improve color support in certain ncurses programs
issue.body: Closes issue #1862, by updating the colors pairs in alacritty.info to use 0x7FFF instead of 0x10000. 0x7FFF is aligned with xterm-256color and solves coloring issues for htop and certain other known ncurses programs.

body: I've created a pull request which fixes this issue. Let me know if you need any other updates or have any comments.

Glad that this has been resolved. Just wanted to mention that at least on my system (arch, with ncurses 6.1), xterm-256color has

```
colors#0x100, cols#80, it#8, lines#24, pairs#0x10000,
```

which is the reason the alacritty terminfo has/had that number to begin with.

Could it be that this is a bug that has been fixed in more recent versions of htop? My htop (version 2.2.0) has no apparent problems with colors with pairs=0x10000.

@dnkl That's not unlikely, since `htop` worked fine for me too. But I guess unless we run into issues with the maximum number of color pairs, going with the lower number that works everywhere should be a safer bet.

@dnkl @chrisduerr  - that is interesting perhaps it's just a mac problem? I'm also using htop 2.2, but the xterm-256color on mac has colors of 0x7FFF (well it has 32767, technically). Agree with chris though, I can't imagine the lower pairs number causing problems, but if it did I suppose we could create a mac terminfo and a linux terminfo?
